item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Substitution Pattern of the Secondary Rim of ICyD Ligand Influences Stereoselectivity
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The substitution pattern of the secondary rim in NHC‐capped cyclodextrin gold complexes significantly influences the reactivity and stereoselectivity of gold‐catalyzed enyne cycloisomerizations. A custom‐designed benzyl‐methyl substitution pattern delivers the highest yields and selectivities.
Abstract The synthesis and evaluation of N‐heterocyclic carbene (NHC)‐capped cyclodextrins with various protecting groups were carried out. The corresponding gold complexes catalyze the stereoselective cycloisomerization of enynes. Permethylation of the cyclodextrin's hydroxyl groups improves yield and selectivity compared to its benzylated counterpart. Notably, alternating methyl and benzyl groups on the secondary rim of the cyclodextrin further enhances asymmetry, achieving even higher enantioselectivities. To synthesize this compound, we optimized the selective deprotection of all benzyl groups at the 2‐position of the sugar residues in the cyclodextrin.
item.content:encoded:
The substitution pattern of the secondary rim in NHC-capped cyclodextrin gold complexes significantly influences the reactivity and stereoselectivity of gold-catalyzed enyne cycloisomerizations. A custom-designed benzyl-methyl substitution pattern delivers the highest yields and selectivities.


Abstract

The synthesis and evaluation of N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC)-capped cyclodextrins with various protecting groups were carried out. The corresponding gold complexes catalyze the stereoselective cycloisomerization of enynes. Permethylation of the cyclodextrin's hydroxyl groups improves yield and selectivity compared to its benzylated counterpart. Notably, alternating methyl and benzyl groups on the secondary rim of the cyclodextrin further enhances asymmetry, achieving even higher enantioselectivities. To synthesize this compound, we optimized the selective deprotection of all benzyl groups at the 2-position of the sugar residues in the cyclodextrin.
item.dc:creator: Guangcan Xu, Olivia Bistri‐Aslanoff, Virginie Mouriès‐Mansuy, Louis Fensterbank, Yongmin Zhang, Sylvain Roland, Matthieu Sollogoub
item.dc:title: Substitution Pattern of the Secondary Rim of ICyD Ligand Influences Stereoselectivity

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Recent Developments for the Ring Opening of Pyrrolidines and Unstrained Cyclic Amines via C–N Bond Cleavage
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: In recent years, the deconstructive transformation of unstrained cyclic amines via C–N bond cleavage has emerged as a powerful strategy for expanding chemical space and facilitating the synthesis of structurally diverse molecules. Notably, advancements in the C–N bond cleavage of pyrrolidine and other unstrained cyclic amines have highlighted the significant potential of this approach in modern organic synthesis. This concept reviews recent developments in the C–N bond cleavage reaction, with a primary focus on pyrrolidines, while also exploring broader progress in related systems.
item.content:encoded: In recent years, the deconstructive transformation of unstrained cyclic amines via C–N bond cleavage has emerged as a powerful strategy for expanding chemical space and facilitating the synthesis of structurally diverse molecules. Notably, advancements in the C–N bond cleavage of pyrrolidine and other unstrained cyclic amines have highlighted the significant potential of this approach in modern organic synthesis. This concept reviews recent developments in the C–N bond cleavage reaction, with a primary focus on pyrrolidines, while also exploring broader progress in related systems.

item.dc:title: Recent Developments for the Ring Opening of Pyrrolidines and Unstrained Cyclic Amines via C–N Bond Cleavage

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Concise Four‐Component Synthesis of Solid‐State Fluorescent α‐Sulfenylated Enaminones
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
α‐Sulfenylated enaminones are accessible in good to excellent yields by a concise consecutive four‐component alkynylation‐addition‐sulfenylation sequence. Most products are strongly solid‐state luminescent with quantum yields up to 84 %. In addition, the absorption characteristics of selected products were rationalized via TD‐DFT calculations.
Abstract Acid chlorides, alkynes, amines, and N‐thiosuccinimides react in a consecutive four‐component alkynylation‐addition‐sulfenylation sequence to give α‐sulfenylated enaminones in good to excellent yields. The terminal sulfenylation step is catalyzed by Yb(OTf)3 and both N‐arylthiosuccinimides and N‐alkylthio succinimides can be successfully employed. Most products are solid‐state luminescent with fluorescence quantum yields up to 84 % and lifetimes up to 4.9 ns. Additionally, TD‐DFT calculations rationalize the electronic structure of the absorption characteristics of the dyes.
item.content:encoded:
α-Sulfenylated enaminones are accessible in good to excellent yields by a concise consecutive four-component alkynylation-addition-sulfenylation sequence. Most products are strongly solid-state luminescent with quantum yields up to 84 %. In addition, the absorption characteristics of selected products were rationalized via TD-DFT calculations.


Abstract

Acid chlorides, alkynes, amines, and N-thiosuccinimides react in a consecutive four-component alkynylation-addition-sulfenylation sequence to give α-sulfenylated enaminones in good to excellent yields. The terminal sulfenylation step is catalyzed by Yb(OTf)3 and both N-arylthiosuccinimides and N-alkylthio succinimides can be successfully employed. Most products are solid-state luminescent with fluorescence quantum yields up to 84 % and lifetimes up to 4.9 ns. Additionally, TD-DFT calculations rationalize the electronic structure of the absorption characteristics of the dyes.
item.dc:creator: Gereon Hendrik Schmitz, Wiebke Kramer, Leonard Karl, Christian Ganter, Thomas J. J. Müller
item.dc:title: Concise Four‐Component Synthesis of Solid‐State Fluorescent α‐Sulfenylated Enaminones

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Ring Opening and C(ω)‐S Coupling: Nickel‐Mediated Transformation of Alicyclic Alkoxyhydroperoxides
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
A ring‐opening ω‐dithiocarbamylation (or ω‐xanthylation) approach based on the unusual intersection of the reactivities of organic peroxides and sulfur‐containing nickel complexes is disclosed. The formation of nickel dithiocarbamate or xanthate complexes and their subsequent interaction with alkoxyhydroperoxide was found to play a key role in the formation of C−S coupling products.
Abstract Ozonolysis of cycloalkanone semicarbazones in alcohol containing solution with the subsequent addition of nickel (II) dithiocarbamates or xanthates was found to result in ω‐xanthyl or ω‐dithiocarbamyl carboxylic acid esters. The reaction proceeds in several steps. The initial one is cycloalkanone semicarbazone ozonolysis in the presence of alcohol, which leads to alicyclic alkoxyhydroperoxide. The second step is an extraordinary interaction between the alkoxyhydroperoxide and nickel (II) dithiocarbamate or xanthate, which proceeds via alkoxy radical formation and its subsequent β‐scission, resulting in C−S coupling products. The developed method allows to obtain ω‐xanthyl or ω‐dithiocarbamyl esters in yields up to 52 % relative to the initial cycloalkanone semicarbazone.
item.content:encoded:
A ring-opening ω-dithiocarbamylation (or ω-xanthylation) approach based on the unusual intersection of the reactivities of organic peroxides and sulfur-containing nickel complexes is disclosed. The formation of nickel dithiocarbamate or xanthate complexes and their subsequent interaction with alkoxyhydroperoxide was found to play a key role in the formation of C−S coupling products.


Abstract

Ozonolysis of cycloalkanone semicarbazones in alcohol containing solution with the subsequent addition of nickel (II) dithiocarbamates or xanthates was found to result in ω-xanthyl or ω-dithiocarbamyl carboxylic acid esters. The reaction proceeds in several steps. The initial one is cycloalkanone semicarbazone ozonolysis in the presence of alcohol, which leads to alicyclic alkoxyhydroperoxide. The second step is an extraordinary interaction between the alkoxyhydroperoxide and nickel (II) dithiocarbamate or xanthate, which proceeds via alkoxy radical formation and its subsequent β-scission, resulting in C−S coupling products. The developed method allows to obtain ω-xanthyl or ω-dithiocarbamyl esters in yields up to 52 % relative to the initial cycloalkanone semicarbazone.
item.dc:creator: Dmitri I. Fomenkov, Roman A. Budekhin, Olga M. Mulina, Olga A. Komarova, Mikhail M. Doronin, Yulia Yu. Belyakova, Liang‐Nian He, Ivan A. Yaremenko, Alexander O. Terent'ev
item.dc:title: Ring Opening and C(ω)‐S Coupling: Nickel‐Mediated Transformation of Alicyclic Alkoxyhydroperoxides

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Determination of the pKaH of Established Isothiourea Catalysts
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
The pKaH of a series of privileged (chiral) isothiourea organocatalysts in acetonitrile and DMSO was determined by using a chemical shift imaging NMR methodology.
Abstract Isothioureas (ITUs) represent a powerful family of (chiral) Lewis base organocatalysts. Interestingly, the Brønsted basicity of these frequently used compounds has so far not systematically been investigated. Thus, we have now determined the pKaH values of the most privileged (chiral) ITUs in acetonitrile (ACN) and DMSO by using NMR. Employing Wallace's chemical shift imaging NMR method, the herein investigated ITUs were found to be weak Brønsted bases with pKaH values in the range of 16.8–17.9 in ACN and 6.3–7.8 in DMSO.
item.content:encoded:
The pKaH of a series of privileged (chiral) isothiourea organocatalysts in acetonitrile and DMSO was determined by using a chemical shift imaging NMR methodology.


Abstract

Isothioureas (ITUs) represent a powerful family of (chiral) Lewis base organocatalysts. Interestingly, the Brønsted basicity of these frequently used compounds has so far not systematically been investigated. Thus, we have now determined the pK aH values of the most privileged (chiral) ITUs in acetonitrile (ACN) and DMSO by using NMR. Employing Wallace's chemical shift imaging NMR method, the herein investigated ITUs were found to be weak Brønsted bases with pK aH values in the range of 16.8–17.9 in ACN and 6.3–7.8 in DMSO.
item.dc:creator: Lukas S. Vogl, Matthias Bechmann, Mario Waser
item.dc:title: Determination of the pKaH of Established Isothiourea Catalysts

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Halogen‐mediated Electrochemical C−N Bond Construction of Amine
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Organic electrochemical synthesis stands out for its environmentally friendly and efficient characteristics. Among these approaches, halogen‐mediated indirect electrosynthesis has gained significant attention as an efficient strategy for C−N bond formation, widely applied in the synthesis of nitrogen‐containing compounds. This review highlights recent advances in direct C−N bond formation processes for various amines under halogen‐mediated electrosynthetic conditions. The features, scope, limitations, and proposed mechanisms of these transformations are discussed in detail. We aim to provide insights into expanding the applicability of halogen‐mediated electrosynthesis, contributing to the development of sustainable synthetic methodologies.
item.content:encoded: Organic electrochemical synthesis stands out for its environmentally friendly and efficient characteristics. Among these approaches, halogen-mediated indirect electrosynthesis has gained significant attention as an efficient strategy for C−N bond formation, widely applied in the synthesis of nitrogen-containing compounds. This review highlights recent advances in direct C−N bond formation processes for various amines under halogen-mediated electrosynthetic conditions. The features, scope, limitations, and proposed mechanisms of these transformations are discussed in detail. We aim to provide insights into expanding the applicability of halogen-mediated electrosynthesis, contributing to the development of sustainable synthetic methodologies.

item.dc:title: Halogen‐mediated Electrochemical C−N Bond Construction of Amine

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Glycosyl Esters as Stable Donors in Chemical Glycosylation
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Glycosyl ester donors represent an important class of donors in recent times to construct complex natural products and oligosaccharides. This review summarizes the past and recent methods involving anomeric esters in glycosylation reactions, including simple esters, alkenyl, alkynyl‐containing esters, carbonate esters, chelation‐assisted glycosyl esters, allenyl and ynenoate glycosyl esters.
Abstract Efficient glycosylation methods are continuously being developed to obtain homogeneously pure carbohydrates to study their biological roles. The development of effective and stereoselective glycosylations using novel anomeric leaving groups constitutes an active area of research in synthetic carbohydrate chemistry. Although various glycosyl donors have been developed over the decades, anomeric esters as donors in glycosylation have received significant attention in recent times due to their convenience of preparation, shelf stability, catalytic activation, mild conditions, and high glycosylation efficiency. We focus in this review on several synthetic strategies for the assembly of the glycosyl ester‐containing donors utilized in chemical glycosylation methods, including simple esters, alkenyl, alkynyl‐containing esters, carbonate esters, chelation‐assisted glycosyl esters, allenyl and ynenoate glycosyl esters in glycoside synthesis are summarized.
item.content:encoded:
Glycosyl ester donors represent an important class of donors in recent times to construct complex natural products and oligosaccharides. This review summarizes the past and recent methods involving anomeric esters in glycosylation reactions, including simple esters, alkenyl, alkynyl-containing esters, carbonate esters, chelation-assisted glycosyl esters, allenyl and ynenoate glycosyl esters.


Abstract

Efficient glycosylation methods are continuously being developed to obtain homogeneously pure carbohydrates to study their biological roles. The development of effective and stereoselective glycosylations using novel anomeric leaving groups constitutes an active area of research in synthetic carbohydrate chemistry. Although various glycosyl donors have been developed over the decades, anomeric esters as donors in glycosylation have received significant attention in recent times due to their convenience of preparation, shelf stability, catalytic activation, mild conditions, and high glycosylation efficiency. We focus in this review on several synthetic strategies for the assembly of the glycosyl ester-containing donors utilized in chemical glycosylation methods, including simple esters, alkenyl, alkynyl-containing esters, carbonate esters, chelation-assisted glycosyl esters, allenyl and ynenoate glycosyl esters in glycoside synthesis are summarized.
item.dc:creator: Sumit Pareek, Pavan Mandadi, Someswara Rao Sanapala
item.dc:title: Glycosyl Esters as Stable Donors in Chemical Glycosylation

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Oxygen Atom Migration of Allylic Esters via an Organocatalyzed Claisen‐type Rearrangement
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, EarlyView.
item.dc:description:
Oxygen atom migration of allylic esters has been reported with 4‐dimethylaminopyridine DMAP as a catalyst. This protocol is compatible with a broad range of functional groups in gram scale. Moreover, corresponding isomerized products exhibit versatile reactivity with a series of nucleophiles to open up a platform for bioactive molecules synthesis.
Abstract Direct transforming molecular skeleton to the other useful one is highly desirable for synthetic chemists. Oxygen atom migration of allylic esters is a powerful avenue for skeleton editing, and various methodologies involving palladium, Lewis acid and cobalt hydride catalysts have been reported. However, these protocols commonly suffer from inferior functional group tolerance and limited preparative application due to the harsh conditions and metal residues. Herein, we report a practical approach for the transformation by using an organocatalyst 4‐dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP). We test this protocol generality and practicality with uniform gram‐scale reactions, and it tolerates with a broad range of functional groups including boric ester, nitrile, ester and others (42 examples). Moreover, corresponding products exhibit versatile reactivity with a series of nucleophiles to open up a platform for bioactive molecules synthesis. A plausible reaction mechanism is proposed to rationalize the experimental observations.
item.content:encoded:
Oxygen atom migration of allylic esters has been reported with 4-dimethylaminopyridine DMAP as a catalyst. This protocol is compatible with a broad range of functional groups in gram scale. Moreover, corresponding isomerized products exhibit versatile reactivity with a series of nucleophiles to open up a platform for bioactive molecules synthesis.


Abstract

Direct transforming molecular skeleton to the other useful one is highly desirable for synthetic chemists. Oxygen atom migration of allylic esters is a powerful avenue for skeleton editing, and various methodologies involving palladium, Lewis acid and cobalt hydride catalysts have been reported. However, these protocols commonly suffer from inferior functional group tolerance and limited preparative application due to the harsh conditions and metal residues. Herein, we report a practical approach for the transformation by using an organocatalyst 4-dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP). We test this protocol generality and practicality with uniform gram-scale reactions, and it tolerates with a broad range of functional groups including boric ester, nitrile, ester and others (42 examples). Moreover, corresponding products exhibit versatile reactivity with a series of nucleophiles to open up a platform for bioactive molecules synthesis. A plausible reaction mechanism is proposed to rationalize the experimental observations.
item.dc:creator: Xiaoli Wang, Ke Liu, Xudong Jin, Xin Li, Mingyu Shen, Sheng Zhang, Man‐Bo Li
item.dc:title: Oxygen Atom Migration of Allylic Esters via an Organocatalyzed Claisen‐type Rearrangement

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Application of Laser‐Generated Au‐Ag/Al2O3 Nanoparticle Catalysts for the Selective Catalytic Oxidation of 5‐(Hydroxymethyl) Furfural to 2,5‐Furan‐Dicarboxylic Acid
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
With reference to the sustainability and green synthesis towards biomass valorization, we report highly active and selective oxidation of the renewable feedstock HMF (78 % conversion) into the commercially important chemical FDCA (80 % selectivity) by implying specially designed and synthesized bimetallic AuAg nanoparticle catalysts supported on Al2O3 by laser ablation under mild basic conditions.
Abstract Conversion of lignocellulosic biomass‐derived 5‐(Hydroxymethyl) furfural (HMF) into 2,5‐Furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) has a high potential to replace petroleum‐based feedstocks for the production of plastics. In this study, a green synthesis strategy for the selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA is reported by using laser‐generated and specifically designed bimetallic AuAg nanoparticle catalysts supported on Al2O3 using molecular oxygen as oxidant and water as a solvent. Although supported AuAg catalysts are already known as suitable catalysts for this reaction, the optimal reaction conditions (type of base, reaction temperature, oxygen pressure), Au : Ag composition, role of metal‐support effects and origin of the active site still remain under debate. Interestingly, an Au9Ag1/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited the highest activity with a FDCA yield of up to 66 % at 80 % HMF conversion. Hereby, NaHCO3 (instead of NaOH) as a smoother base in 2 : 1 base:HMF ratio, low oxygen pressures of 5 bar, and a mild temperature of 150 °C were found optimal. The yield remained fairly stable on reuse of the catalyst for 3 cycles without hints of catalyst sintering or leaching. The titration of surficial hydroxyls on the AuxAgy/Al2O3 surface showed the highest density of acidic hydroxyls for the most active Au9Ag1/Al2O3 catalyst. The respective hydroxyls potentially originate from metal‐support interactions between the AuAg nanoparticles with the alumina support and act as Lewis acidic sites that oxidize the alcohol moiety of HMF to form FDCA with high selectively. In summary, this study shows that the catalytic activity of AuAg catalysts in HMF oxidation is not just linked to an alloying effect but also to a metal‐support effect where the AuAg nanoparticles appear to directly affect the local acidity of the support.
item.content:encoded:
With reference to the sustainability and green synthesis towards biomass valorization, we report highly active and selective oxidation of the renewable feedstock HMF (78 % conversion) into the commercially important chemical FDCA (80 % selectivity) by implying specially designed and synthesized bimetallic AuAg nanoparticle catalysts supported on Al2O3 by laser ablation under mild basic conditions.


Abstract

Conversion of lignocellulosic biomass-derived 5-(Hydroxymethyl) furfural (HMF) into 2,5-Furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) has a high potential to replace petroleum-based feedstocks for the production of plastics. In this study, a green synthesis strategy for the selective oxidation of HMF to FDCA is reported by using laser-generated and specifically designed bimetallic AuAg nanoparticle catalysts supported on Al2O3 using molecular oxygen as oxidant and water as a solvent. Although supported AuAg catalysts are already known as suitable catalysts for this reaction, the optimal reaction conditions (type of base, reaction temperature, oxygen pressure), Au : Ag composition, role of metal-support effects and origin of the active site still remain under debate. Interestingly, an Au9Ag1/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited the highest activity with a FDCA yield of up to 66 % at 80 % HMF conversion. Hereby, NaHCO3 (instead of NaOH) as a smoother base in 2 : 1 base:HMF ratio, low oxygen pressures of 5 bar, and a mild temperature of 150 °C were found optimal. The yield remained fairly stable on reuse of the catalyst for 3 cycles without hints of catalyst sintering or leaching. The titration of surficial hydroxyls on the AuxAgy/Al2O3 surface showed the highest density of acidic hydroxyls for the most active Au9Ag1/Al2O3 catalyst. The respective hydroxyls potentially originate from metal-support interactions between the AuAg nanoparticles with the alumina support and act as Lewis acidic sites that oxidize the alcohol moiety of HMF to form FDCA with high selectively. In summary, this study shows that the catalytic activity of AuAg catalysts in HMF oxidation is not just linked to an alloying effect but also to a metal-support effect where the AuAg nanoparticles appear to directly affect the local acidity of the support.
item.dc:creator: Samrin Shaikh, Tobias Esser, Jan Söder, Sven Reichenberger, Jakob Albert
item.dc:title: Application of Laser‐Generated Au‐Ag/Al2O3 Nanoparticle Catalysts for the Selective Catalytic Oxidation of 5‐(Hydroxymethyl) Furfural to 2,5‐Furan‐Dicarboxylic Acid

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Activation of Alkenes via Chalcogen Bond: Chalcogen⋅⋅⋅π Bond Catalyzed the Diels‐Alder Reaction of 2‐Vinylindoles
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
The present study investigates the stepwise mechanism of the Diels‐Alder reaction of 2‐vinylindoles catalyzed by chalcogen⋅⋅⋅π bond. Furthermore, the activation of alkene through Te⋅⋅⋅π bond serves as an alternative strategy to drive this reaction. The reaction catalyzed by Se⋅⋅⋅π and Te⋅⋅⋅π bonds involves the endo and exo pathways, and the endo product is more easily obtained.
Abstract Chalcogen bond catalysis is a promising catalytic strategy, characterized by its environmental friendliness, relatively inexpensive cost, and similar reactivity to transition metal catalysis. Experimental results suggest that the S⋅⋅⋅π and Se⋅⋅⋅π bonds can efficiently drive the vinyl‐indole‐based Diels‐Alder reaction (Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2021, 60, 9395–9400). In this work, chalcogen bond catalysis in the Diels‐Alder reaction between 2‐vinylindoles is investigated based on density functional theory. For this reaction, the Te⋅⋅⋅π bond catalysis is as an alternative catalytic strategy. The Diels‐Alder reaction catalyzed by chalcogen bond is stepwise and involves two steps: the carbon–carbon bond formation process and the cyclization process. The cyclization process is the rate‐determining step. From the perspective of energy decomposition analysis, the electrostatic interaction is the main factor to cause Se⋅⋅⋅π bond catalysis, the polarization interaction is the main factor to cause Te⋅⋅⋅π bond catalysis. Additionally, this catalytic reaction involves the endo pathway and exo pathway. The Gibbs free energy barrier values of the endo pathway are lower than those of the exo pathway, which facilitates the formation of the endo product. This study will provide a valuable perspective on the application of chalcogen bond in the activation of alkenes.
item.content:encoded:
The present study investigates the stepwise mechanism of the Diels-Alder reaction of 2-vinylindoles catalyzed by chalcogen⋅⋅⋅π bond. Furthermore, the activation of alkene through Te⋅⋅⋅π bond serves as an alternative strategy to drive this reaction. The reaction catalyzed by Se⋅⋅⋅π and Te⋅⋅⋅π bonds involves the endo and exo pathways, and the endo product is more easily obtained.


Abstract

Chalcogen bond catalysis is a promising catalytic strategy, characterized by its environmental friendliness, relatively inexpensive cost, and similar reactivity to transition metal catalysis. Experimental results suggest that the S⋅⋅⋅π and Se⋅⋅⋅π bonds can efficiently drive the vinyl-indole-based Diels-Alder reaction (Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2021, 60, 9395–9400). In this work, chalcogen bond catalysis in the Diels-Alder reaction between 2-vinylindoles is investigated based on density functional theory. For this reaction, the Te⋅⋅⋅π bond catalysis is as an alternative catalytic strategy. The Diels-Alder reaction catalyzed by chalcogen bond is stepwise and involves two steps: the carbon–carbon bond formation process and the cyclization process. The cyclization process is the rate-determining step. Additionally, this catalytic reaction involves the endo pathway and exo pathway. The Gibbs free energy barrier values of the endo pathway are lower than those of the exo pathway, which facilitates the formation of the endo product. This study will provide a valuable perspective on the application of chalcogen bond in the activation of alkenes.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Synthesis of 1,4‐Naphthoquinones via Palladium(II)‐Catalyzed Tertiary C−H Alkylation of Olefins Followed by C−C Bond Cleavage
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
An efficient method has been developed for the preparation of 1,4‐naphthoquinones via a palladium‐catalyzed reaction of 2‐aryl‐1,3‐indandiones with olefins. This reaction involves the tertiary C−H alkylation of 2‐aryl‐1,3‐indandiones with olefins to produce a tertiary alcohol, followed by C−C bond cleavage.
Abstract An efficient method has been developed for the preparation of 1,4‐naphthoquinones via a palladium‐catalyzed reaction of 2‐aryl‐1,3‐indandiones with olefins. This reaction involves the tertiary C−H alkylation of 2‐aryl‐1,3‐indandiones with olefins to produce a tertiary alcohol, followed by C−C bond cleavage.
item.content:encoded:
An efficient method has been developed for the preparation of 1,4-naphthoquinones via a palladium-catalyzed reaction of 2-aryl-1,3-indandiones with olefins. This reaction involves the tertiary C−H alkylation of 2-aryl-1,3-indandiones with olefins to produce a tertiary alcohol, followed by C−C bond cleavage.


Abstract

An efficient method has been developed for the preparation of 1,4-naphthoquinones via a palladium-catalyzed reaction of 2-aryl-1,3-indandiones with olefins. This reaction involves the tertiary C−H alkylation of 2-aryl-1,3-indandiones with olefins to produce a tertiary alcohol, followed by C−C bond cleavage.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Tandem, Catalyst‐Free C−C Synthesis of Nitriles from Aldehydes and Methyl Cyanoacetate with Sodium Hypophosphite
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Herein we have reported a reaction that allows performing a Knoevenagel condensation, its adduct reduction, and subsequent decarboxylation in a single preparative step using cheap, stable, and convenient sodium hypophosphite. No metal catalyst is required. The reaction is scalable. The limitations of the method are also described in the paper.
Abstract Saturated carbon chain elongation is a common refrain in numerous synthetic pathways. While the formation of C−C single bonds is of primary importance in organic synthesis, the simultaneous introduction of functional groups such as nitrile or ester can reasonably increase its practical utility for the preparation of multifunctional products. The Knoevenagel reaction is a powerful tool to create carbon backbones of organic molecules; however, it requires subsequent reduction and/or decarboxylation to achieve a product with a saturated carbon chain. Herein we report a convenient one‐step protocol for the reductive condensation between methyl cyanoacetate and aldehydes in the presence of stable, ecologically benign, cheap and available in bulk amounts sodium hypophosphite as a reductant. A description of both the reaction capabilities and limitations is given in this paper.
item.content:encoded:
Herein we have reported a reaction that allows performing a Knoevenagel condensation, its adduct reduction, and subsequent decarboxylation in a single preparative step using cheap, stable, and convenient sodium hypophosphite. No metal catalyst is required. The reaction is scalable. The limitations of the method are also described in the paper.


Abstract

Saturated carbon chain elongation is a common refrain in numerous synthetic pathways. While the formation of C−C single bonds is of primary importance in organic synthesis, the simultaneous introduction of functional groups such as nitrile or ester can reasonably increase its practical utility for the preparation of multifunctional products. The Knoevenagel reaction is a powerful tool to create carbon backbones of organic molecules; however, it requires subsequent reduction and/or decarboxylation to achieve a product with a saturated carbon chain. Herein we report a convenient one-step protocol for the reductive condensation between methyl cyanoacetate and aldehydes in the presence of stable, ecologically benign, cheap and available in bulk amounts sodium hypophosphite as a reductant. A description of both the reaction capabilities and limitations is given in this paper.
item.dc:creator: Vasily Korochantsev, Artemy Fatkulin, Evgeniya Podyacheva, Alexander Boldyrev, Oleg I. Afanasyev, Denis Chusov
item.dc:title: Tandem, Catalyst‐Free C−C Synthesis of Nitriles from Aldehydes and Methyl Cyanoacetate with Sodium Hypophosphite

item.title: Rapid and General Access to α‐Halogenated Carbonyl Compounds Using Amidine Halide Salts as Halogen Sources under Mild Conditions
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A convenient strategy for the halogenation reaction of diazo compounds in the presence of TfOH with amidine ⋅ HX (X=Cl, Br, I) salts as halogen sources and demonstrate a broad substrate scope in good to excellent yields at room temperature. This protocol is characterized by mild reaction conditions, metal‐free, simplicity and also features good functional group tolerance, good to excellent yields and a broad substrate scope with 37 examples.
Abstract Rapid and efficient construction of α‐haloketones with diazo compounds and amidine ⋅ HX (X=Cl, Br, I) salts as halogen sources has been recognized as a simple and practical strategy. The reaction exhibits a broad scope and scalability, thereby enabling synthesis of a broad spectrum of functionally orchestrated α‐haloketones under mild and metal‐free conditions in a short time. Control experiments established the involvement of triffate 10 in the mechanism.
item.content:encoded:
A convenient strategy for the halogenation reaction of diazo compounds in the presence of TfOH with amidine ⋅ HX (X=Cl, Br, I) salts as halogen sources and demonstrate a broad substrate scope in good to excellent yields at room temperature. This protocol is characterized by mild reaction conditions, metal-free, simplicity and also features good functional group tolerance, good to excellent yields and a broad substrate scope with 37 examples.


Abstract

Rapid and efficient construction of α-haloketones with diazo compounds and amidine ⋅ HX (X=Cl, Br, I) salts as halogen sources has been recognized as a simple and practical strategy. The reaction exhibits a broad scope and scalability, thereby enabling synthesis of a broad spectrum of functionally orchestrated α-haloketones under mild and metal-free conditions in a short time. Control experiments established the involvement of triffate 10 in the mechanism.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Stereo‐ and Chemoselective Enrichment of sp3 Character in Post‐Ugi Morpholines
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A comprehensive study aimed at reducing the degree of unsaturation and consequently increasing the sp3 character in post‐Ugi morpholines is conducted. The scaffold assembly involves triphenylphosphine‐promoted umpolung oxa‐Michael cyclization of Ugi adducts derived from propiolic acid and glycolaldehyde dimer. Diastereoselective heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation, combined with chemoselective amide reduction, enables the controlled modulation of the morpholine core‘s rigidity.
Abstract We conducted a systematic study on synthesis and modification of morpholine core using Ugi adducts derived from propiolic acid and glycolaldehyde dimer. The assembly step involved triphenylphosphine‐promoted 6‐exo‐dig umpolung oxa‐Michael cyclization of Ugi‐derived hydroxypropargylamides yielding 2‐methylenemorpholin‐3‐one derivatives. Subsequent heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation of the exocyclic double bond proceeded in a highly diastereoselective fashion establishing a relative cis configuration in the resulting sp3‐enriched morpholinone scaffold. Finally, chemoselective amide reduction with lithium aluminum hydride (LAH) allowed to obtain fully saturated morpholines while leaving the more sterically hindered exocyclic amide moiety intact. Taken together these findings outline the strategy for controlled reduction of the inherent rigidity of post‐Ugi scaffolds.
item.content:encoded:
A comprehensive study aimed at reducing the degree of unsaturation and consequently increasing the sp3 character in post-Ugi morpholines is conducted. The scaffold assembly involves triphenylphosphine-promoted umpolung oxa-Michael cyclization of Ugi adducts derived from propiolic acid and glycolaldehyde dimer. Diastereoselective heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation, combined with chemoselective amide reduction, enables the controlled modulation of the morpholine core‘s rigidity.


Abstract

We conducted a systematic study on synthesis and modification of morpholine core using Ugi adducts derived from propiolic acid and glycolaldehyde dimer. The assembly step involved triphenylphosphine-promoted 6-exo-dig umpolung oxa-Michael cyclization of Ugi-derived hydroxypropargylamides yielding 2-methylenemorpholin-3-one derivatives. Subsequent heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation of the exocyclic double bond proceeded in a highly diastereoselective fashion establishing a relative cis configuration in the resulting sp3-enriched morpholinone scaffold. Finally, chemoselective amide reduction with lithium aluminum hydride (LAH) allowed to obtain fully saturated morpholines while leaving the more sterically hindered exocyclic amide moiety intact. Taken together these findings outline the strategy for controlled reduction of the inherent rigidity of post-Ugi scaffolds.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Chemical Synthesis of β‐(1,4)‐d‐Oligomannurarates with Purported Anti‐Alzheimer Activity
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Herein, we develop an efficient approach to the chemical synthesis of well‐defined β‐(1,4)‐d‐mannurarate di‐, tetra‐, hexa‐ and octasaccharides with purported anti‐Alzheimer's activity, utilizing N‐phenyl trifluoroacetimidate donors and thioglycoside acceptors for the stereoselective assembly of the desired β‐(1,4)‐d‐mannuronate linkages.
Abstract Sodium oligomannate, a sophisticated mixture of acidic linear β‐(1,4)‐d‐oligomannurarate ranging from dimers to decamers with an average molecular weight of 670∼880 Da, has gained conditional approval for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease. Herein, we develop an efficient approach to the chemical synthesis of well‐defined β‐(1,4)‐d‐mannurarate di‐, tetra‐, hexa‐ and octasaccharides (1–4), utilizing N‐phenyl trifluoroacetimidate donors and thioglycoside acceptors for the stereoselective assembly of the desired β‐(1,4)‐d‐mannuronate linkages. This approach features a straightforward protecting group strategy with only two types of protecting groups: tert‐butyldimethylsilyl (TBS) for the 4‐OH at the non‐reducing end and benzyl (Bn) for free hydroxyl and carboxylic acid moieties, thereby ensuring the stereoselective formation of the β‐mannosyl bonds and facilitating sequential transformation into the target β‐(1,4)‐d‐mannurarate oligosaccharides. The scalability of the present synthesis of these oligosaccharides paves the way for in‐depth structure‐activity relationship studies and pharmacological investigations of sodium oligomannates.
item.content:encoded:
Herein, we develop an efficient approach to the chemical synthesis of well-defined β-(1,4)-d-mannurarate di-, tetra-, hexa- and octasaccharides with purported anti-Alzheimer's activity, utilizing N-phenyl trifluoroacetimidate donors and thioglycoside acceptors for the stereoselective assembly of the desired β-(1,4)-d-mannuronate linkages.


Abstract

Sodium oligomannate, a sophisticated mixture of acidic linear β-(1,4)-d-oligomannurarate ranging from dimers to decamers with an average molecular weight of 670∼880 Da, has gained conditional approval for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease. Herein, we develop an efficient approach to the chemical synthesis of well-defined β-(1,4)-d-mannurarate di-, tetra-, hexa- and octasaccharides (1–4), utilizing N-phenyl trifluoroacetimidate donors and thioglycoside acceptors for the stereoselective assembly of the desired β-(1,4)-d-mannuronate linkages. This approach features a straightforward protecting group strategy with only two types of protecting groups: tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBS) for the 4-OH at the non-reducing end and benzyl (Bn) for free hydroxyl and carboxylic acid moieties, thereby ensuring the stereoselective formation of the β-mannosyl bonds and facilitating sequential transformation into the target β-(1,4)-d-mannurarate oligosaccharides. The scalability of the present synthesis of these oligosaccharides paves the way for in-depth structure-activity relationship studies and pharmacological investigations of sodium oligomannates.
item.dc:creator: Xiaofei Shao, Peng Xu, Biao Yu
item.dc:title: Chemical Synthesis of β‐(1,4)‐d‐Oligomannurarates with Purported Anti‐Alzheimer Activity

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Palladium‐Catalyzed Intermolecular [5+2] Cycloaddition: Highly Regioselective Synthesis of Allene‐Containing 2‐Benzoxepines
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A method for the synthesis of allene‐containing 2‐benzoxepines has been developed on the basis of palladium‐catalyzed intermolecular [5+2] cycloaddition. The synthetic approach features ready substrate availability, broad substrate scope, satisfactory yields and excellent regioselectivity.
Abstract Palladium‐catalyzed intermolecular [5+2] cycloaddition of propargylic carbonates with benzyl allenyl ethers has been developed for the synthesis of allene‐containing 2‐benzoxepines. The reaction proceeds by a pathway involving decarboxylative allenylpalladium formation, regioselective intermolecular insertion, and intramolecular nucleophilic attack. In this way, the sequential formation of C−C and C−O bonds results in the generation of a 2‐benzoxepine skeleton in a one‐pot process.
item.content:encoded:
A method for the synthesis of allene-containing 2-benzoxepines has been developed on the basis of palladium-catalyzed intermolecular [5+2] cycloaddition. The synthetic approach features ready substrate availability, broad substrate scope, satisfactory yields and excellent regioselectivity.


Abstract

Palladium-catalyzed intermolecular [5+2] cycloaddition of propargylic carbonates with benzyl allenyl ethers has been developed for the synthesis of allene-containing 2-benzoxepines. The reaction proceeds by a pathway involving decarboxylative allenylpalladium formation, regioselective intermolecular insertion, and intramolecular nucleophilic attack. In this way, the sequential formation of C−C and C−O bonds results in the generation of a 2-benzoxepine skeleton in a one-pot process.
item.dc:creator: Bingyu Shen, Aimei Yang, Xihong Lu, Zhijun Xin, Xuehu Li
item.dc:title: Palladium‐Catalyzed Intermolecular [5+2] Cycloaddition: Highly Regioselective Synthesis of Allene‐Containing 2‐Benzoxepines

item.title: Facile N‐Modification of NH‐Tetrazoles via Rh(II)‐Catalyzed N−H Insertion Involving Structurally Diverse Diazo Reagents
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A convenient method for the N‐modification of NH‐tetrazoles by the Rh(II)‐catalyzed insertion reaction of diazocarbonyl compounds into the N‐H bond has been proposed. A wide scope of structurally diverse diazo reagents as well as tetrazoles with different substituents in the fifth position have been used to prepare disubstituted tetrazole derivatives in good and high yields and with high regioselectivity.
Abstract A convenient method for the N‐modification of NH‐tetrazoles by the Rh(II)‐catalyzed insertion reaction of diazocarbonyl compounds into the N−H bond has been proposed. A wide range of structurally diverse diazo reagents (including heterocyclic ones) as well as tetrazoles with different substituents in the fifth position have been used to prepare 2,5‐disubstituted tetrazole derivatives in good and high yields and with high regioselectivity. It is shown that the regioselectivity of the reaction can decrease in the presence of electron withdrawing groups in the tetrazole, as well as in the presence of protic acids.
item.content:encoded:
A convenient method for the N-modification of NH-tetrazoles by the Rh(II)-catalyzed insertion reaction of diazocarbonyl compounds into the N-H bond has been proposed. A wide scope of structurally diverse diazo reagents as well as tetrazoles with different substituents in the fifth position have been used to prepare disubstituted tetrazole derivatives in good and high yields and with high regioselectivity.


Abstract

A convenient method for the N-modification of NH-tetrazoles by the Rh(II)-catalyzed insertion reaction of diazocarbonyl compounds into the N−H bond has been proposed. A wide range of structurally diverse diazo reagents (including heterocyclic ones) as well as tetrazoles with different substituents in the fifth position have been used to prepare 2,5-disubstituted tetrazole derivatives in good and high yields and with high regioselectivity. It is shown that the regioselectivity of the reaction can decrease in the presence of electron withdrawing groups in the tetrazole, as well as in the presence of protic acids.
item.dc:creator: Valentin Radiupov, Grigory Kantin, Dmitry Dar'in
item.dc:title: Facile N‐Modification of NH‐Tetrazoles via Rh(II)‐Catalyzed N−H Insertion Involving Structurally Diverse Diazo Reagents

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: 1,4‐Dioxane as Precursor of −CH2CH2−: A Simple and Convenient Strategy to Synthesize 1,2‐Disulfide Substituted Ethanes Initiated by Iodine
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A novel precursor of −CH2CH2− has been achieved via the double C−O cleavage of 1,4‐dioxane under the proton acid condition of HI. Control experiments suggest that 1,2‐diiodoethane generated in‐situ is crucial for the formation of the product. This protocol for the construction of various 1,2‐disulfide substituted ethanes is very convenient and practical by its simple and mild conditions.
Abstract An unprecedented I2‐initiated nucleophilic ring opening reaction of 1,4‐dioxane with thiols for the construction of various 1,2‐disulfide substituted ethanes has been developed. Previously, dihalogenated ethane, acetylene or ethylene are often used as the pre‐cursor of −CH2CH2−. Through the cleavage of two C−O bonds, 1,4‐dioxane as precursor of −CH2CH2− has been achieved for the first time. In the presence of HI, thiols could be replaced by disulfides as nucleophile. This protocol is very convenient and practical by its simple and mild conditions.
item.content:encoded:
A novel precursor of −CH2CH2− has been achieved via the double C−O cleavage of 1,4-dioxane under the proton acid condition of HI. Control experiments suggest that 1,2-diiodoethane generated in-situ is crucial for the formation of the product. This protocol for the construction of various 1,2-disulfide substituted ethanes is very convenient and practical by its simple and mild conditions.


Abstract

An unprecedented I2-initiated nucleophilic ring opening reaction of 1,4-dioxane with thiols for the construction of various 1,2-disulfide substituted ethanes has been developed. Previously, dihalogenated ethane, acetylene or ethylene are often used as the pre-cursor of −CH2CH2−. Through the cleavage of two C−O bonds, 1,4-dioxane as precursor of −CH2CH2− has been achieved for the first time. In the presence of HI, thiols could be replaced by disulfides as nucleophile. This protocol is very convenient and practical by its simple and mild conditions.
item.dc:creator: Yufeng Liu, Wentao Xie, Zhen Wei, Lili Geng, Cengceng Du, Xiaoning Shen
item.dc:title: 1,4‐Dioxane as Precursor of −CH2CH2−: A Simple and Convenient Strategy to Synthesize 1,2‐Disulfide Substituted Ethanes Initiated by Iodine

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Photocatalytic Decarboxylative Fluoroalkylation of α,β‐Unsaturated Carboxylic Acids
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A universal decarboxylation–fluoroalkylation method involving the coupling of α,β‐unsaturated carboxylic acids with α‐CF3 alkyl bromides was developed by the use of dual nickel/photoredox catalysis. A wide variety of substrates bearing a diverse set of functional groups underwent the transformation to afford trifluoromethyl analogues of α‐methylated allylic compounds under very mild conditions.
Abstract A decarboxylative fluoroalkylation of α,β‐unsaturated acids was developed by the use of a dual nickel/photoredox catalysis system. The fluoroalkyl radicals are generated from α‐CF3 alkyl bromides by nickel‐induced single electron transfer (SET) and are subsequently intercepted by a cinnamic acid to forge the targeted C−C bonds. A wide variety of substrates bearing a diverse set of functional groups were compatible with the mild reaction conditions (visible light, room temperature, cheap metal, no strong oxidant or reductant), thus affording trifluoromethyl analogues of α‐methylated allylic compounds.
item.content:encoded:
A universal decarboxylation–fluoroalkylation method involving the coupling of α,β-unsaturated carboxylic acids with α-CF3 alkyl bromides was developed by the use of dual nickel/photoredox catalysis. A wide variety of substrates bearing a diverse set of functional groups underwent the transformation to afford trifluoromethyl analogues of α-methylated allylic compounds under very mild conditions.


Abstract

A decarboxylative fluoroalkylation of α,β-unsaturated acids was developed by the use of a dual nickel/photoredox catalysis system. The fluoroalkyl radicals are generated from α-CF3 alkyl bromides by nickel-induced single electron transfer (SET) and are subsequently intercepted by a cinnamic acid to forge the targeted C−C bonds. A wide variety of substrates bearing a diverse set of functional groups were compatible with the mild reaction conditions (visible light, room temperature, cheap metal, no strong oxidant or reductant), thus affording trifluoromethyl analogues of α-methylated allylic compounds.
item.dc:creator: Xiuling Wang, Yaxing Wu, Songlin Xu, Hongmei Qu, Chao Chen
item.dc:title: Photocatalytic Decarboxylative Fluoroalkylation of α,β‐Unsaturated Carboxylic Acids

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: On the Halogenation of Tyrosine N‐Oxime Methyl Ester
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Building blocks derived from tyrosine N‐oxime have been used to construct natural products. We report the synthesis of nine halogenated tyrosine N‐oxime derivatives reminiscent of biosynthetic precursors. Full conversion was ensured by the addition of p‐toluenesulfonic acid (p‐TsOH) for monohalogenation and a key oxidation‐reduction sequence using excess N‐bromo, N‐chloro, or N‐iodosuccinimide (NBS, NCS, NIS) to provide dihalogenated derivatives.
Abstract Efficient syntheses of mono‐, di‐, and heterodihalogenated derivatives of tyrosine N‐oxime methyl ester are reported. Monohalogenation with N‐bromosuccinimide (NBS), N‐chlorosuccinimide (NCS) or N‐iodosuccinimide (NIS) was optimized by addition of acid to suppress dihalogenation, affording bromo, chloro, and iodo derivatives in 71 %, 50–53 %, and 78–80 % yields, respectively. Homodihalogenation utilized a two‐step, one‐flask process via a spirocyclic intermediate, yielding dibromo, dichloro, and diiodo analogues, respectively (75–76 %, 54–56 %, 79–80 %). This strategy was extended to synthesize hetero‐dihalogenated bromochloro, bromoiodo, and chloroiodo derivatives from monohalogenated analogues (50–77 %). Key to this approach was the formation of an oxidized spirocyclic intermediate using excess N‐halosuccinimide, followed by Na₂S₂O₄ reduction. This method ensures complete conversion and simplifies purification. Nine halogenated building blocks were prepared. These methods provide practical access to versatile precursors for natural product synthesis and derivatization, offering potential for diverse synthetic applications including regioselective palladium‐catalyzed couplings.
item.content:encoded:
Building blocks derived from tyrosine N-oxime have been used to construct natural products. We report the synthesis of nine halogenated tyrosine N-oxime derivatives reminiscent of biosynthetic precursors. Full conversion was ensured by the addition of p-toluenesulfonic acid (p-TsOH) for monohalogenation and a key oxidation-reduction sequence using excess N-bromo, N-chloro, or N-iodosuccinimide (NBS, NCS, NIS) to provide dihalogenated derivatives.


Abstract

Efficient syntheses of mono-, di-, and heterodihalogenated derivatives of tyrosine N-oxime methyl ester are reported. Monohalogenation with N-bromosuccinimide (NBS), N-chlorosuccinimide (NCS) or N-iodosuccinimide (NIS) was optimized by addition of acid to suppress dihalogenation, affording bromo, chloro, and iodo derivatives in 71 %, 50–53 %, and 78–80 % yields, respectively. Homodihalogenation utilized a two-step, one-flask process via a spirocyclic intermediate, yielding dibromo, dichloro, and diiodo analogues, respectively (75–76 %, 54–56 %, 79–80 %). This strategy was extended to synthesize hetero-dihalogenated bromochloro, bromoiodo, and chloroiodo derivatives from monohalogenated analogues (50–77 %). Key to this approach was the formation of an oxidized spirocyclic intermediate using excess N-halosuccinimide, followed by Na₂S₂O₄ reduction. This method ensures complete conversion and simplifies purification. Nine halogenated building blocks were prepared. These methods provide practical access to versatile precursors for natural product synthesis and derivatization, offering potential for diverse synthetic applications including regioselective palladium-catalyzed couplings.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Iodine‐Assisted Regioselective C3‐H Chalcogenation of 4‐Phenyl Aminocoumarin: Access to Unusual Dual Selenylation of N‐Substituted Derivatives
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
A straightforward metal and photocatalyst‐free iodine‐dependent green protocol of chalcogenation of 4‐phenyl aminocoumarin/4‐phenylamino‐2‐pyrone, as well as abnormal dual selenylation of N‐ substituted‐4‐phenyl aminocoumarin, has been developed at room temperature and ambient air in green solvent PEG‐400.
Abstract A simple, efficient, metal and photocatalyst‐free, eco‐friendly approach for the C3‐H regioselective chalcogenation of 4‐phenyl aminocoumarin, as well as abnormal dual selenylation of N‐substituted 4‐phenyl aminocoumarin, has been developed by using diphenyl dichalcogenides and iodine as support in green solvent PEG‐400 under ambient temperature and aerobic condition. Furthermore, chalcogenation of 4‐phenyl amino‐2‐pyrone has also been accomplished in similar conditions. The proposed mechanism is based on the control experiments and suggests an ionic pathway. The reaction offers a green synthetic path with a high yield, and the methodology is crucially significant due to its operational simplicity, convenient execution, scalability, and tolerance of various functional groups.
item.content:encoded:
A straightforward metal and photocatalyst-free iodine-dependent green protocol of chalcogenation of 4-phenyl aminocoumarin/4-phenylamino-2-pyrone, as well as abnormal dual selenylation of N- substituted-4-phenyl aminocoumarin, has been developed at room temperature and ambient air in green solvent PEG-400.


Abstract

A simple, efficient, metal and photocatalyst-free, eco-friendly approach for the C3-H regioselective chalcogenation of 4-phenyl aminocoumarin, as well as abnormal dual selenylation of N-substituted 4-phenyl aminocoumarin, has been developed by using diphenyl dichalcogenides and iodine as support in green solvent PEG-400 under ambient temperature and aerobic condition. Furthermore, chalcogenation of 4-phenyl amino-2-pyrone has also been accomplished in similar conditions. The proposed mechanism is based on the control experiments and suggests an ionic pathway. The reaction offers a green synthetic path with a high yield, and the methodology is crucially significant due to its operational simplicity, convenient execution, scalability, and tolerance of various functional groups.

item.dc:title: Iodine‐Assisted Regioselective C3‐H Chalcogenation of 4‐Phenyl Aminocoumarin: Access to Unusual Dual Selenylation of N‐Substituted Derivatives

item.title: Iodine(III)‐Mediated Unexpected Ring‐Contraction Rearrangement and Halogenated Addition Reaction to Synthesize 3‐Substituted Phthalides and Isochroman‐1‐One Derivatives
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Using a system mediated by iodine(III) and tetrabutylammonium halides, unexpected ring‐contraction rearrangement and halogenation addition reaction of isocoumarins were achieved, resulting in the formation of 3‐substituted phthalides and isochroman‐1‐one derivatives.
Abstract Iodine(III)‐mediated ring‐contraction rearrangement and halogenated addition reaction have been realized. A series of 3‐substituted phthalides and isochroman‐1‐one derivatives bearing multiple functional groups were obtained in good to excellent yields under mild reaction conditions. Computational studies indicated that the reaction proceeds via a proton transfer followed by ring opening and ring formation to produce the target product. Moreover, preliminary biological evaluations revealed that both of 3‐substituted phthalides and isochroman‐1‐one derivatives show good antitumor activities.
item.content:encoded:
Using a system mediated by iodine(III) and tetrabutylammonium halides, unexpected ring-contraction rearrangement and halogenation addition reaction of isocoumarins were achieved, resulting in the formation of 3-substituted phthalides and isochroman-1-one derivatives.


Abstract

Iodine(III)-mediated ring-contraction rearrangement and halogenated addition reaction have been realized. A series of 3-substituted phthalides and isochroman-1-one derivatives bearing multiple functional groups were obtained in good to excellent yields under mild reaction conditions. Computational studies indicated that the reaction proceeds via a proton transfer followed by ring opening and ring formation to produce the target product. Moreover, preliminary biological evaluations revealed that both of 3-substituted phthalides and isochroman-1-one derivatives show good antitumor activities.

item.dc:title: Iodine(III)‐Mediated Unexpected Ring‐Contraction Rearrangement and Halogenated Addition Reaction to Synthesize 3‐Substituted Phthalides and Isochroman‐1‐One Derivatives

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: (3+3)‐Annulation of 2‐Mercaptobenzimidazoles With α‐(Trifluoromethyl)Styrene Under Ultrasonic Irradiation
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
This protocol developed (3+3)‐annulation of 2‐mercaptobenzimidazoles with α‐(trifluoromethyl)styrene under ultrasonic irradiation. The cyclized product was formed through the Michael addition and intramolecular substitution reaction successively. The pure products were obtained with simple recrystallization.
Abstract A rapid and facile sonochemical route for the [3+3] annulation of 2‐mercapto benzimidazoles with α‐(trifluoromethyl)styrene was reported for the synthesis of fluorinated benzo[4,5]imidazo[2,1‐b][1,3]thiazines. The reaction proceeds through the SN2/SNV pathway while the selective SN2 pathway is completely inhibited. The developed method is effective with a wide range of substrates, tolerating diverse functional groups. The pure products are obtained with high yield (up to 92 %) directly via recrystallization without column chromatography. Furthermore, applying sonochemical methodology reduces the reaction time and eliminates the need for expensive photocatalysts, ligands or oxidants.
item.content:encoded:
This protocol developed (3+3)-annulation of 2-mercaptobenzimidazoles with α-(trifluoromethyl)styrene under ultrasonic irradiation. The cyclized product was formed through the Michael addition and intramolecular substitution reaction successively. The pure products were obtained with simple recrystallization.


Abstract

A rapid and facile sonochemical route for the [3+3] annulation of 2-mercapto benzimidazoles with α-(trifluoromethyl)styrene was reported for the synthesis of fluorinated benzo[4,5]imidazo[2,1-b][1,3]thiazines. The reaction proceeds through the SN2/SNV pathway while the selective SN2 pathway is completely inhibited. The developed method is effective with a wide range of substrates, tolerating diverse functional groups. The pure products are obtained with high yield (up to 92 %) directly via recrystallization without column chromatography. Furthermore, applying sonochemical methodology reduces the reaction time and eliminates the need for expensive photocatalysts, ligands or oxidants.
item.dc:creator: Akbar Sohail, Keyume Ablajan, Shahid Ali Khan
item.dc:title: (3+3)‐Annulation of 2‐Mercaptobenzimidazoles With α‐(Trifluoromethyl)Styrene Under Ultrasonic Irradiation

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Visible‐Light‐Induced Mpg‐C3N4 Catalyzed C(sp2)−H Thiocyanation of Ketene Dithioacetals
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
Using mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride (mpg‐C3N4) as a metal‐free heterogeneous photocatalyst was developed for thiocyanation of alkenes under visible light irradiation with oxygen as green oxidant and without any other additives. The present protocol has excellent functional group tolerance and the desired tetrasubstituted alkenyl thiocyanides were obtained in moderate to good yields. Moreover, the recyclable mpg‐C3N4 catalyst could be used at least 6 times without significant loss of activities.
Abstract Using mesoporous graphite carbon nitride (mpg‐C3N4) as metal‐free heterogeneous catalyst, the thiocyanation of ketene dithioacetals was achieved under visible light irradiation with oxygen as green oxidant and without any other additives. The present protocol has excellent functional group tolerance and the desired tetrasubstituted alkenyl thiocyanides were obtained in moderate to good yields. Moreover, the recyclable mpg‐C3N4 catalyst could be used at least 6 times without significant loss of activities. A series of mechanistic validation experiments indicated that the reaction involves a radical process.
item.content:encoded:
Using mesoporous graphitic carbon nitride (mpg-C3N4) as a metal-free heterogeneous photocatalyst was developed for thiocyanation of alkenes under visible light irradiation with oxygen as green oxidant and without any other additives. The present protocol has excellent functional group tolerance and the desired tetrasubstituted alkenyl thiocyanides were obtained in moderate to good yields. Moreover, the recyclable mpg-C3N4 catalyst could be used at least 6 times without significant loss of activities.


Abstract

Using mesoporous graphite carbon nitride (mpg-C3N4) as metal-free heterogeneous catalyst, the thiocyanation of ketene dithioacetals was achieved under visible light irradiation with oxygen as green oxidant and without any other additives. The present protocol has excellent functional group tolerance and the desired tetrasubstituted alkenyl thiocyanides were obtained in moderate to good yields. Moreover, the recyclable mpg-C3N4 catalyst could be used at least 6 times without significant loss of activities. A series of mechanistic validation experiments indicated that the reaction involves a radical process.
item.dc:creator: Fumeng Yin, Shan Hu, Shuwei Zhu, Shifeng Xing, Hongjun Zhu
item.dc:title: Visible‐Light‐Induced Mpg‐C3N4 Catalyzed C(sp2)−H Thiocyanation of Ketene Dithioacetals

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Photooxidation of Polystyrene into High‐Value Chemicals
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
This review provides an overview of recent studies in the photooxidative degradation of polystyrene into benzoyl compounds. It includes a comparative analysis of various degradation methods, highlighting their effectiveness and efficiency. Additionally, the review discusses the underlying mechanisms involved in the degradation process and addresses the challenges that remain in this field.
Abstract Plastics play a crucial role in the survival and advancement of human civilization. However, the increasing challenge of plastic pollution presents significant obstacles. Disposal methods such as incineration and landfilling result in substantial resource wastage and pose potential environmental hazards. The slow progress in recycling and reusing waste plastics hinders their industrial application and effective response to environmental crises. Photocatalysis offers promising solutions for the future of plastic recycling, particularly with the recent increase in photocatalytic degradation methods for polystyrene (PS). This review provides a comprehensive overview of the latest advancements in the photooxidation of PS into high‐value chemicals.

Abstract

Plastics play a crucial role in the survival and advancement of human civilization. However, the increasing challenge of plastic pollution presents significant obstacles. Disposal methods such as incineration and landfilling result in substantial resource wastage and pose potential environmental hazards. The slow progress in recycling and reusing waste plastics hinders their industrial application and effective response to environmental crises. Photocatalysis offers promising solutions for the future of plastic recycling, particularly with the recent increase in photocatalytic degradation methods for polystyrene (PS). This review provides a comprehensive overview of the latest advancements in the photooxidation of PS into high-value chemicals.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Recent Advances in the Hydroxylation of Boronic Acids
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
In recent years, substantial progress has been achieved in the synthesis of hydroxylated compounds from boronic acids. This review summarizes the representative methods over the past decade. The paper categorizes these methods based on the types of catalysts employed, encompassing a range of metal catalysts and non‐metal catalysts, as well as other reaction types of catalyst‐free.
Abstract Hydroxylated compounds represent a significant and diverse class of substances in the field of chemistry. These compounds play critical roles in various chemical reactions and are essential components in numerous industrial applications. Recent years have witnessed remarkable advancements in the synthesis of hydroxylated compounds, especially those derived from boronic acids. The synthesis of hydroxylated compounds from boronic acids typically involves the utilization of various types of catalysts, which are essential for enhancing reaction rates and selectivity, including metal catalysts such as CuFe₂O₄, Cu@C₃N₄, AgNPs, and Ti0.97Ni0.3O1.97, as well as non‐metal catalysts like polycaprolactone (PCL), TFB‐BMTH COF materials, C70, and graphene oxide (GO). These catalytic reactions often require the addition of oxidants such as hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) or molecular oxygen, which serve as critical reagents in the hydroxylation process. In certain cases, organic bases act as electron donors to propel the reaction. Furthermore, some studies have reported oxidative hydroxylation reactions that are catalyst‐free.This review aims to summarize the recent advancements and breakthroughs in the synthesis of hydroxylated compounds from boronic acids, with a particular focus on research conducted from 2014 to 2024.
item.content:encoded:
In recent years, substantial progress has been achieved in the synthesis of hydroxylated compounds from boronic acids. This review summarizes the representative methods over the past decade. The paper categorizes these methods based on the types of catalysts employed, encompassing a range of metal catalysts and non-metal catalysts, as well as other reaction types of catalyst-free.


Abstract

Hydroxylated compounds represent a significant and diverse class of substances in the field of chemistry. These compounds play critical roles in various chemical reactions and are essential components in numerous industrial applications. Recent years have witnessed remarkable advancements in the synthesis of hydroxylated compounds, especially those derived from boronic acids. The synthesis of hydroxylated compounds from boronic acids typically involves the utilization of various types of catalysts, which are essential for enhancing reaction rates and selectivity, including metal catalysts such as CuFe₂O₄, Cu@C₃N₄, AgNPs, and Ti0.97Ni0.3O1.97, as well as non-metal catalysts like polycaprolactone (PCL), TFB-BMTH COF materials, C70, and graphene oxide (GO). These catalytic reactions often require the addition of oxidants such as hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) or molecular oxygen, which serve as critical reagents in the hydroxylation process. In certain cases, organic bases act as electron donors to propel the reaction. Furthermore, some studies have reported oxidative hydroxylation reactions that are catalyst-free.This review aims to summarize the recent advancements and breakthroughs in the synthesis of hydroxylated compounds from boronic acids, with a particular focus on research conducted from 2014 to 2024.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Research Progress of Rhodium(III)‐Catalyzed C(sp2)−H Bond Functionalization
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Volume 28, Issue 4, January 24, 2025.
item.dc:description:
This review highlights the advancements of rhodium‐catalyzed C(sp2)−H bond activation. We discuss the ongoing challenges of selectivity, particularly in remote (meta/para) C(sp2)−H bond functionalization, and the reliance on directing groups. Insights from 2018 to 2024 are categorized by reaction type, revealing mechanistic developments that promise enhanced efficiency and broader applications.
Abstract Over the past decade, rhodium‐catalyzed C−H bond activation reactions have made significant progress and found broad applications in organic synthesis, biomedicine, and materials science. This is primarily attributed to their broad substrate scope, excellent functional group compatibility, and high reactivity. Currently, although considerable progress has been made, rhodium‐catalyzed C(sp2)−H functionalization still heavily relies on directing groups to achieve selectivity, which significantly diminishes the reaction's efficiency. Additionally, the challenge of selectively functionalizing remote (meta/para) C−H bonds further complicates research in this field. In this review, we primarily focus on the research progress in rhodium‐catalyzed C(sp2)−H functionalization from 2018 to 2024, categorizing reactions by type and providing a systematic overview of the mechanistic insights for each.
item.content:encoded:
This review highlights the advancements of rhodium-catalyzed C(sp2)−H bond activation. We discuss the ongoing challenges of selectivity, particularly in remote (meta/para) C(sp2)−H bond functionalization, and the reliance on directing groups. Insights from 2018 to 2024 are categorized by reaction type, revealing mechanistic developments that promise enhanced efficiency and broader applications.


Abstract

Over the past decade, rhodium-catalyzed C−H bond activation reactions have made significant progress and found broad applications in organic synthesis, biomedicine, and materials science. This is primarily attributed to their broad substrate scope, excellent functional group compatibility, and high reactivity. Currently, although considerable progress has been made, rhodium-catalyzed C(sp2)−H functionalization still heavily relies on directing groups to achieve selectivity, which significantly diminishes the reaction's efficiency. Additionally, the challenge of selectively functionalizing remote (meta/para) C−H bonds further complicates research in this field. In this review, we primarily focus on the research progress in rhodium-catalyzed C(sp2)−H functionalization from 2018 to 2024, categorizing reactions by type and providing a systematic overview of the mechanistic insights for each.

item.title: An Operationally Simple, Regioselective, Platinum‐Catalyzed Hydroboration of Unactivated Alkynes
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Herein is reported a new PtCl2/XPhos/Et3SiH‐catalyzed hydroboration method for unactivated terminal alkynes. Significantly, the reaction proceeds in hindered alkyne systems, and works well on acetylenes that contain multiple heteroatom‐groups to provide the desired (E)‐1,2‐vinyl boronates in reasonable to high yields with excellent levels of stereo‐ and regio‐control.

item.source: Wiley: European Journal of Organic Chemistry: Table of Contents
item.title: Photoinduced DNA cleavage using bioinspired photostable flavin analogues
item.description: European Journal of Organic Chemistry, Accepted Article.
item.dc:description: Inspired by the photosensitization capability of the naturally occurring flavin derivatives, viz. riboflavin (RF),flavin mononucleotide (FMN), flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) and their photodegradation susceptibility due to the presence of ribityl/phosphate group; the current manuscript investigates the N10‐modified flavin analogues for their reactive oxygen species (ROS) generating capability and DNA cleavage activity, when irradiated with blue light. The effectiveness of superoxide anion generating property of photoexcited flavin analogs were determined using nitro blue tetrazolium (NBT) and gallic acid quenching experiments. Among the flavin analogues studied, the simple propylflavin (PFl) was found to be most photostable and efficient in the conditions studied. The carboxyl‐flavin (10Flc) displays behavior like that of FMN while the flavin‐aspartic acid conjugate (FA) was found to show properties in between the PF and the 10Flc.
item.content:encoded: Inspired by the photosensitization capability of the naturally occurring flavin derivatives, viz. riboflavin (RF),flavin mononucleotide (FMN), flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) and their photodegradation susceptibility due to the presence of ribityl/phosphate group; the current manuscript investigates the N10-modified flavin analogues for their reactive oxygen species (ROS) generating capability and DNA cleavage activity, when irradiated with blue light. The effectiveness of superoxide anion generating property of photoexcited flavin analogs were determined using nitro blue tetrazolium (NBT) and gallic acid quenching experiments. Among the flavin analogues studied, the simple propylflavin (PFl) was found to be most photostable and efficient in the conditions studied. The carboxyl-flavin (10Flc) displays behavior like that of FMN while the flavin-aspartic acid conjugate (FA) was found to show properties in between the PF and the 10Flc.
